text: The blog post <https://www.owlfolio.org/development/autoconf-swot/|https://www.owlfolio.org/development/autoconf-swot/> is dated January 29th :tardis:
> Libtool has opinions about the proper way to manage shared libraries that Linux distributions actively disagree with, forcing them to kludge around its code during package builds.

elements.text: Libtool has opinions about the proper way to manage shared libraries that Linux distributions actively disagree with, forcing them to kludge around its code during package builds.
Autoconf and Automake support cross-compilation better than competing build systems.

text: It still depends on the project

elements.text: It still depends on the project

Building an Autotools-based project directly from its VCS checkout is often significantly harder than building it from a tarball release, and may involve tracking down and installing any number of unusual tools
One of the reasons why I prefer the release tarballs, if available, as opposed to using a GitSource
The Autotools depend on other GNU software that is not actively maintained, most importantly GNU M4, and to a lesser extent GNU Make

text:
> We are pleased to announce stable release 2.70 of GNU Autoconf.
> 
> This release includes eight years of development work since the
> previous release, 2.69.  Noteworthy changes include support for the
> 2011 revisions of the C and C++ standards
> 
Just in time :sweat_smile:

elements.text: We are pleased to announce stable release 2.70 of GNU Autoconf.
This release includes eight years of development work since the
previous release, 2.69.  Noteworthy changes include support for the
2011 revisions of the C and C++ standards
